We define Cğ¶C as the set of clients distributed over a disjunct set of power domainsÂ Pğ‘ƒP.
Clients are characterized by their energy efficiencyÂ Î´csubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{c} and maximum computing capacityÂ mcsubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{c}.
For simplicity, we do not consider other resources like memory in this work, but they can be integrated the same way as mcsubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{c}.
We divide time into slots of duration tğ‘¡t, so an estimated training round duration dğ‘‘d is always a multiple of tğ‘¡t.
The duration of tğ‘¡t depends on the problem setting but is usually in the order of one minute.
We define the training of a mini-batch, from now on called batch, as an atomic operation to be performed within these time slots.
TableÂ 1 provides an overview of all introduced variables and constants.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2. Max energy consumption and training performance of the three types of clients.
S5.T2.table:
client max performance (samples per minute)
type energy DenseNet-121 EfficientNet-B1 LSTM KWT-1
small 70 W 110 118 276 87
mid 300 W 384 411 956 303
large 700 W 742 795 1856 586
references:
Clients.Â Â 
We model heterogeneity among clients by randomly assigning them to one of three types (small, medium, large) that are roughly based on the performance333https://developer.nvidia.com/deep-learning-performance-training-inference and energy usage characteristics of T4, V100, and A100 GPUs, respectively.
However, we downscaled their actual compute capabilities (samples per minute), as shown in TableÂ 2.
We use 100 randomly selected machines from the Alibaba GPU cluster trace datasetÂ (Weng etÂ al., 2022) to model client load (gpu_wrk_util) and load forecasts (gpu_plan).

The number of samples computed per timestep was obtained through benchmarking runs and is stated in TableÂ 2.
All simulations use a timestep t=1ğ‘¡1t=1â€‰ min and a max round duration dmax=60superscriptğ‘‘max60d^{\text{max}}=60â€‰min.
We select n=10ğ‘›10n=10 clients each round which have to compute 1 to 5 local epochs, so mmâ€‹iâ€‹nsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›m^{min} and mmâ€‹aâ€‹xsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥m^{max} depend on the locally available number of samples.
Clients locally train on minibatches of size 10.
We ran each experiment five times over the course of seven simulated days and report mean values.

Time-to-accuracy and energy-to-accuracy.Â Â 
To further demonstrate how FedZero improves FL under energy and capacity constraints, we define the top accuracy of the Random baseline as our target accuracy for a specific experiment.
TableÂ 3 reports the time and energy required for FedZero and the baselines to reach this target accuracy.
The table only contains the best-performing baselines; a full table with all results can be found in AppendixÂ A.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4. CIFAR-100 performance on the global scenario under imbalanced conditions (Berlin has unlimited resources).
S5.T4.table:
Best accuracy Time-to-acc. Energy-to-acc.
Random 64.6 % 6.7 d 95.7 kWh
Oort 65.6 % 4.5 d 189.4 kWh
FedZero 66.9 % 3.5 d 83.4 kWh
references:
TableÂ 4 displays the training performance of the three approaches in the scenario where Berlin has unlimited resources.
We observe that Random used 19â€‰% more energy and Oort even twice the energy in the imbalanced scenario (FigureÂ LABEL:fig:eval_fairness-b) for reaching a comparable accuracy as in the base scenario (FigureÂ LABEL:fig:eval_fairness-a).
FedZero used only 4â€‰% more energy and reduced its time-to-accuracy.
